items.title: How to use Chat Actions
items.text: To use any of the following options, simply go to the Inbox section of Messcat and right-click the chat that you want to perform the action on.

items.title: Pin/Unpin Chat
items.text:
• Pin: Keeps the chat at the top of your inbox for easy access, regardless of incoming messages.
  • Unpin: Removes the chat from the pinned section, allowing it to return to its original position in the inbox.

items.title: Mute/Unmute Notifications
items.text:
• Mute: Temporarily disables notifications for the selected chat, so you won't be alerted about new messages.
  • Unmute: Re-enables notifications, so you can receive alerts for new messages in the chat.

items.title: Archive Chat
items.text: • Archive: Moves the chat to the archive, keeping it out of your main inbox but retaining all the chat data for future reference.

items.title: Mark Chat as Unread/Read
items.text:
• Mark as Unread: Resets the chat‚Äôs status, marking it as unread and highlighting it as a new message in your inbox.
  • Mark as Read: Marks the chat as read and removes any unread message indicator.

items.title: Clear All Pending Messages
items.text: • Clear Pending: Removes all pending (delayed) messages from the chat, ensuring no delayed actions are left.

items.title: Clear All Cancelled Messages
items.text: • Clear Cancelled: Deletes all cancelled messages in the chat, whether manually or automatically cancelled via message flows.

items.title: Refresh
items.text: • Refresh: Reloads the chat, ensuring that all messages and updates are current.

items.title: Export Chat History
items.text: • Export: Allows you to download the entire chat history for record-keeping or analysis purposes.

items.title: Export Media (Last 48 Hours)
items.text: • Export Media: Downloads all media files (images, videos, documents) shared within the last 48 hours in the chat.

items.title: Delete Chat
items.text:
• Delete: Permanently deletes the chat and all its messages.
‚ÄºÔ∏è This will delete the chat and its message contents from WhatsApp on your mobile as well

items.title: How to use Filters?
items.text:
[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Gyx8xpNoSR8khz18YJ0Ej8x6qsatDem0/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Gyx8xpNoSR8khz18YJ0Ej8x6qsatDem0/view?usp=sharing)

Inbox filters are a powerful tool to help you manage your messages and organize conversations more efficiently. By using filters, you can streamline your workflow, focus on what matters most, and boost your productivity.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
Inbox filters allow you to:

  • Sort Through Messages: Categorize conversations based on specific criteria like unread messages, channels, or assigned tags.
  • Focus on What Matters: Filter your inbox to prioritize conversations that require immediate attention.
  • Boost Productivity: Spend less time searching and more time engaging with customers.

items.title: Available Filters
items.text: Here are the different filters you can apply to organize your inbox:

items.title: Channel
items.text: • Filter by Channel: Sort contacts based on the channel where their number is saved (e.g., WhatsApp, SMS).

items.title: Tag
items.text:
You can apply tag filters in two ways:

  • Tag is: Filters all contacts with the selected tag(s) applied.
  • Tag is not: This works as an additional filter. For example, if you filter by Tag is "A" and want to exclude contacts with Tag B, you can use Tag is not "B" to display only contacts with Tag A but exclude those with Tag B.

Additionally, you can filter by:

  • Date Range: When the tag was added.
  • Team Member: Who added the tag.

items.title: Custom Fields
items.text:
Filter based on custom fields in two ways:

  • Selected Custom Field: Shows contacts that have data within the selected custom field.
  • Custom is or is not: Applies as a second condition for the selected custom field.

For example, filtering by Birthday with is "January" will show all contacts with a birthday in January. If you add is not "February", contacts with a birthday in February will be excluded.

Additionally, you can filter by:

  • Date Range: When the custom field data was added.
  • Team Member: Who added the custom field data.

Example: Filter by the "Purchase Value" custom field to find contacts with a purchase value recorded by the sales team between January 1st and March 31st.

items.title: Assignee
items.text:
• Filter by Assignee: Filters contacts based on which team member they are assigned to. You can include or exclude contacts assigned to specific team members.

Additionally, you can filter by:

  • Date Range: When the contact was assigned.
  • Team Member: Who assigned the contact.

items.title: Ticket
items.text: • Filter by Ticket: Sort contacts based on whether they have tickets in a specific CRM board or at a particular stage within that board.

items.title: More Options
items.text:
The 'More' option provides additional filters:

  • Unread: View messages you haven‚Äôt opened yet.
  • Archived: View archived chats.
  • @Mentions: View chats where you‚Äôve been mentioned.
  • Unsolved Notes: View contacts with unresolved notes/comments.
  • Groups: Show only group chats in the inbox.
  • Individuals: Show only individual contacts in the inbox.
  • Chats Not Replied: Show chats that haven't been replied to.
  • Message Queue: Show chats with pending or scheduled messages.
  • Failed Messages: Show chats where messages could not be sent due to errors.

items.title: Pinning Filters
items.text: Pinning filters allows you to quickly access and organize your most frequently used or important filters.

items.title: How to Pin Filters
items.text:
1. Select the filters you want to apply.
  2. Click Pin Filter and give it a name.

To delete or rename pinned filters, click the edit icon next to your pinned filters.

Simplify Workflows

items.text: You can combat this by setting a keyword reply for such messages to let customers know that you are not able to view the message. They can ask the customer to send it again or send any other response.
path: Fixing the 'This message is not available' Error for Keyword Reply

items.title: Steps
items.text:
Here's how to set up an auto-response for unavailable messages:

  1. Prepare a message flow that asks the customer to resend their message or provide an alternative response. Example:

  2. Navigate to "Automation" > "Keyword Reply" from the left sidebar

  3. Click [Create] in the top-right corner
  4. Set condition to [Message Exactly Is] and enter "ciphertext" as the keyword

  5. Select the message flow you created in step 1

  6. Enable [Only Reply to New Message] in Advanced Settings to prevent duplicate responses

  7. Click [Save] to finish setup.
path: Fixing the 'This message is not available' Error for Keyword Reply

items.title: Problem
items.text: When you try to edit a message using the "/" shortcut in the inbox, sometimes the changes aren't saved and the original message is sent instead. This issue occurs occasionally, particularly on older devices or with slower network connections. While this isn't a common problem, it can be frustrating when it happens.
path: Troubleshooting Message Flow Edit Issues in the Inbox

items.title: Affected Devices
items.text:
• HP Laptop 15s-fq5xxx
  • Lenovo IdeaCentre 510S-07ICB
path: Troubleshooting Message Flow Edit Issues in the Inbox

items.title: Potential Causes
items.text:
• Device Limitations
    • Devices with limited processing power and memory may have trouble running complex web applications, causing glitches or delays.
    • Devices with outdated software or hardware are more likely to have compatibility issues.
  • Network Connectivity Issues
    • Poor or unstable network connections can disrupt real-time updates and cause unexpected behavior.
  • Browser-Specific Bugs
    • Some browser versions, particularly on older devices, have bugs that can affect text input fields.
path: Troubleshooting Message Flow Edit Issues in the Inbox

items.title: Troubleshooting Steps
items.text:
1. Check Browser Version: Ensure you're running Chrome version 130.0.6723.92 or higher for best results.
  2. Clear Browser Cache: Clear your browser's cache and cookies through settings for a fresh start.
  3. Try a Different Browser: Switch to another supported browser, such as Chrome or Safari.
  4. Test on Different Networks: Connect to a different network to determine if the problem is network-related.
  5. Test on Different Devices: If available, access the application on another device to check if the issue persists.
path: Troubleshooting Message Flow Edit Issues in the Inbox

items.title: Additional Information
items.text:
If these steps don't solve the problem, please submit a support ticket or contact our team.

  • Provide Device and Browser Details: Please provide details about your device (e.g., model, operating system) and the browser you are using.
  • Share Screenshots: If possible, share screenshots of the issue to help us understand the problem better.

We are actively investigating this intermittent issue and working on a permanent solution. We apologize for any inconvenience caused and appreciate your patience.

items.title: FAQ for Analytics
items.text:
How to Access Multiple Dashboards? Click on the Dashboard Dropdown as shown below and select the dashboard you want to access.

How to add a new Dashboard?

Click on the Dashboard Selector Dropdown, then click on create new dashboard.

How to Change the Time Period in Analytics and Toggle Between Daily, Weekly, and Monthly Views

  1. Click on the dropdown menu labeled "Last 4 weeks" (or the current time period) at the top of the dashboard.
  2. Select the desired time range from the available options (e.g., Last 4 weeks, Month to date, Year to date, etc.).
  3. To toggle between different data views, such as Daily, Weekly, or Monthly, click on the dropdown menu next to the time period selector and choose your preferred interval.

How to Customize Your Dashboard by Adding Data

  1. Click the "Add Data" button in the top right corner of your dashboard.
  2. You can choose from the four types of data available to add to your dashboard:
    • Messages Exchanged: The total number of messages exchanged on the platform by your team.
    • Reply Speed: The average time taken to reply to a message. Only counted when the reply is within 24 hours.
    • Messages Opened: The percentage of messages that were opened (read) by the recipient.
    • New Chats: The number of new unique chats initiated.
  3. Select the desired type of data, and it will be added to your dashboard, allowing you to personalize your view.

How to change the Graph Type for your data?

  • Step 1: Click the Table icon at the top of the chart.

  • Step 2: Choose from the available graph types:
    • Table: Displays your data in a tabular format.
    • Line Chart: Visualizes trends over time using lines.
    • Pie Chart: Shows data distribution in a circular format, great for comparing parts of a whole.
    • Snapshot: Provides a quick visual summary of your data.

items.title: How to use filters to analyse data?
items.text:
How to Filter Your Data in Analytics

The filter feature allows you to refine the data displayed in your charts by selecting specific conditions, making it easier to focus on the insights that matter most.
path: How to use filters to analyse data?

items.title: Steps to Filter Your Data:
items.text:
1. Select a Chart

    • Start by selecting the chart you want to filter. For this example, we'll use the Messages Exchanged chart.

  2. Access the Filter Options

    • Click on the Filter icon (as shown in the image) at the top of the chart. This will open a list of filter options specific to the type of data in the chart.

  3. Choose the Filter Criteria

    • From the list of available filters, you can choose how to refine your data. For example, if you want to see the breakdown of Incoming vs. Outgoing messages, you can select those options in the filter list.

  4. Apply the Filter

    • Once you‚Äôve selected your filter criteria (e.g., Incoming and Outgoing messages), the chart will automatically update to show only the filtered data. This allows you to focus on specific types of messages or other categories depending on your selected data.
path: How to use filters to analyse data?

items.title: Example:
items.text:
In the Messages Exchanged chart, selecting Incoming and Outgoing from the filter menu will show you the number of messages received and sent separately. This helps in analyzing specific patterns in messaging behavior, such as team performance in handling incoming messages versus outgoing communication efforts.

Messages Exchanged filtered by Outgoing Messages.

Messages Exchanged filtered by Incoming Messages.
path: How to use filters to analyse data?

items.title: How to use powerful breakdowns?
items.text:
How to Use the Breakdown Feature in Analytics

The Breakdown feature allows you to dissect your data based on different categories, giving you deeper insights into specific segments of your analytics.

items.title: Steps to Use the Breakdown Feature:
items.text:
1. Add New Data or Select an Existing Chart

    • If you haven‚Äôt added data yet, follow the instructions in the help document on adding new data. Alternatively, you can click on any of the existing charts in your dashboard.

  2. Access the Breakdown Options

    • Once you‚Äôve selected a chart, click on the Line Chart icon located at the top of the widget (as shown in the images). This will open the list of available breakdown options. The options available for breakdown will vary depending on the type of data displayed in the chart.

  3. Choose a Breakdown Category

    • From the list, select the category you want to break down the data by. For example, if you are analyzing Messages Exchanged, you can choose to break it down by Country, as shown in the images.

  4. View the Breakdown Results

    • Once you‚Äôve selected your breakdown category, the chart or table will update to show you the data based on your chosen filter. For instance, if you selected Country for the Messages Exchanged chart, you will now see a breakdown showing how many messages were exchanged with each country.

This feature helps you quickly identify which categories or segments are contributing the most to your overall metrics, allowing for more strategic decisions.

Note: If you want to change the chart type, click on the table icon.

items.title: How to use filters and breakdowns together?
path: How to use filters and breakdowns together?

items.title: How to Use the Filter and Breakdown Features Together
items.text: You can combine the Filter and Breakdown features to gain more specific insights and design a powerful, customized dashboard.

items.text:
1. Apply a Filter
    • Select the Messages Exchanged chart.
    • Click the Filter icon at the top of the chart.
    • From the available options, select WhatsApp Business API (or any channel) to filter the data by that channel.
    • The chart will now show only the messages exchanged via your WhatsApp Business API channel.
  2. Apply a Breakdown
    • After applying the filter, click the Breakdown (Line Chart) icon.
    • Choose Country as the breakdown category.
    • Now, the chart will display a breakdown of messages exchanged by Country, but only for the filtered WhatsApp Business API channel.
  3. Result:
    • The data now reflects the WhatsApp Business API channel and shows the number of messages exchanged, broken down by each country.

items.title: Combining Filters and Breakdowns
items.text:
This feature is flexible, allowing you to apply filters and breakdowns in multiple combinations depending on the data type. For example, you could filter by team member and break down by message type, creating a more powerful and customized view of your data.

This combination of filtering and breakdowns helps you dig deeper into your metrics, making it easier to analyze specific aspects of your business performance.

items.title: How to share your Analytics Dashboard with your team?
path: How to share your Analytics Dashboard with your team?

items.title: Default Sharing of Analytics Dashboard
items.text:
By default, your Analytics dashboard will be visible to your teammates to view. This will let them view the dashboard, and apply filters for their use, but they won‚Äôt be allowed to save these changes. This means that, the changes made will not be the default or apply to everyone‚Äôs board, just theirs, till the page is refreshed, or they get edit access.

However, in some cases you may want to change the access your teammates have, giving them more access, to edit the dashboard, apply some changes and save them for everyone, or you may choose to hide the dashboard from them, restricting their access.
path: How to share your Analytics Dashboard with your team?

items.title: How to Edit Access?
items.text:
Step 1: To edit access, find the share button, (only visible if you‚Äôre the owner of the board), and click on it.

Step 2: You will see the following Modal. Here you will see ‚ÄúAll Teammates‚Äù as an option and also all your other teammates. Continue reading to learn more about how these options work.

All Teammates sets the default access level for all your teammates. If you want all your teammates to view, edit or have no access. Then make the changes to this option from the dropdown.

Individual Teammate‚Äì If you want to give access to some users that is more or less than your default, then you can select the individual teammate and change their access. This will not impact the default setting for the rest of your teammates, only the selected teammate.

Helpful in scenarios where you might want to share your board to view with all your teammates, but give someone edit access, and also hide the board from some other member.

The teammates who have specifically modified access will not have Default written in their setting. If you change one of your teammates access, but change your mind later and want to give them the default level access, change their individual dropdown back to default.

Step 3: Save your changes!
path: How to share your Analytics Dashboard with your team?

items.title: Some Important Notes on Edit Access and its Functionality
items.text:
• By default it should give all team members view access
  • Allows sharing with "All Teammates" with say "edit" access but then give some specific teammate "view" access, i.e. allow teammate specific overrides.
  • Should allow only users with edit access to change dashboard name and filters/data/etc.
  • Only dashboard owners can delete the dashboard and share the dashboard
  • Users with view access can make changes to their dashboard but cannot save. To save, read next point‚Äì
  • If a user with view access makes some changes, and then without refreshing the page, acquires edit access from their teammate (their teammate gives them edit access on their end), it should change the users access automatically and let them save their changes (there should be no loss of changes).
path: How to share your Analytics Dashboard with your team?

items.title: Default Dashboard Overview (OLD)
items.text:
Default Dashboard Overview

When you create your first dashboard, you'll see a set of default widgets that give you insights into key metrics for your team‚Äôs performance. Here‚Äôs what each graph shows:

  1. New Chats Breakdown

    This chart displays the number of new chats initiated within the selected time period. It breaks down chats into two categories:

    • Incoming: Chats started by your customers.
    • Outgoing: Chats initiated by your team.The percentage change from the previous cycle is also displayed to give a quick overview of the trend in new chats.

  2. Messages Exchanged Breakdown

    This chart shows the total number of messages exchanged on the platform during the selected time period. Like the New Chats Breakdown, it is split into:

    • Incoming: Messages received by your team.
    • Outgoing: Messages sent by your team.The percentage change from the last cycle helps you track whether message activity is increasing or decreasing.

  3. Message Open Rate

    This section shows the percentage of messages that were opened (or read) by recipients. You‚Äôll also see a breakdown by different categories like:

    • WA Business: Messages sent via WhatsApp Business.
    • WABA Malaysia: WhatsApp Business API in Malaysia.
    • Other channels as configured.The red arrow indicates the percentage decrease compared to the previous cycle.

  4. Messages Sent via Automation

    This chart tracks the total number of messages sent through automated flows or notifications. It provides a breakdown into two categories:

    • Message Flow: Automated messages triggered by workflows.
    • Notifications: Pre-set messages such as reminders or alerts.The percentage change helps you assess the effectiveness and usage of your automation.

  5. Messages Sent by Team Members

    This graph displays the total number of messages sent by different team members, allowing you to compare individual performance. You‚Äôll see a breakdown of:

    • Automation: Messages sent via automation.
    • Admin: Messages sent by administrators.
    • Other team members by name.The percentage change from the last cycle highlights shifts in team member activity.
    • None indicates messages sent outside Messcat.

  6. Average Reply Speed

    This chart shows the average time it takes your team to reply to incoming messages. You‚Äôll also see the average reply time for each team member or automated system:

    • None: Represents messages sent outside Messcat.
    • Automation: Average reply speed for automated replies.
    • Individual team members by name. A red arrow indicates that the average reply speed has increased compared to the previous cycle, while a green arrow would show an improvement.

This default dashboard provides a comprehensive view of your team's messaging performance, helping you quickly understand where improvements or adjustments might be needed.

items.title: Overview
items.text: The Call Logs page allows you to review all the calls made and received, with detailed information about each call. This page includes filtering options, a comprehensive list of call logs, and the ability to view detailed call information.

items.title: Call Logs List
items.text:
The list of call logs includes the following columns:

  • Contact Name: The name of the contact.
  • To (Number of Contact): The phone number of the contact called.
  • From (Number Used to Call): The phone number used to make the call.
  • Date: The date and time when the call was made.
  • Duration: The duration of the call.
  • Recording: A button to download the recording if the call was recorded.
  • Call Notes: Any notes taken during the call.

items.title: Viewing Call Details
items.text:
Clicking on a call log entry opens the call details, as shown in the image below:

The call details include:

  • Contact Information:
    • Contact name and phone number.
    • Options to go to their chat in the inbox page or make another call.
  • Call Recording:
    • An audio player to play the recording (if the call was recorded).
    • A download button to download the recording.
  • Call Notes:
    • Displays the call notes if they were taken.
    • If no notes were taken, it will display "No call notes available!"
‚ùó **Important Notes: ‚Ä¢** The entries with a duration and no recording are calls where the record call toggle was turned off. **‚Ä¢** Entries that have a recording, but no duration are calls that were placed and then immediately cut. There will still be a very small recording made by our calls API provider.

items.text:
The Phone Numbers page allows you to manage the phone numbers associated with your account for calling purposes. You can add, verify, and manage phone numbers through this interface.

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1iz4xnkaLekuHjDDUuzf8VufXBzcHnjPA/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1iz4xnkaLekuHjDDUuzf8VufXBzcHnjPA/view?usp=sharing)

items.title: Adding a Phone Number
items.text:
To add a new phone number, follow these steps:

  1. Click "Add your phone number":
    • Navigate to the Phone Numbers page and click on the button labeled "Add your phone number".
  2. Enter Details in the Dialog Box:
    • A dialog box will appear prompting you to enter your phone number and name.
    • Fill in the fields with the relevant information.
    • Click on "Get Code" to generate a verification code.
  3. Verify Your Phone Number:
    • A code will appear in the dialog box.
    • When you receive the verification call, enter this code using the number pad on your phone.
    • Click "Confirm" to complete the verification process.
üìå **Verification Process**: ‚Ä¢ Ensure that you have access to the phone number you are adding, as you will receive a verification call where you need to enter the code displayed in the dialog box. ‚Ä¢ Make sure that international incoming calls are available from your network provider, as the verification call will be an overseas call.
path: How to add a Phone Number

items.title: Managing Phone Numbers
items.text:
• Edit Name:
    • You can edit the name associated with the phone number by clicking the "Edit" button.
  • Delete Phone Number:
    • If you need to change the phone number, you must delete the existing number and add a new one.
    • To delete, click the "Delete" button next to the phone number.
‚úèÔ∏è **Editing Restrictions**: Only the name of the phone number can be edited. To change the phone number itself, deletion and re-adding are required. ‚ùó **Important Notice**: Effective August 1, 2024, calls placed from +91 numbers are blocked and will return the error code that you are seeing. Due to local regulations on domestic calls in India, our API provider will no longer support outbound calls from Indian numbers (+91).
path: How to add a Phone Number

items.title: Overview
items.text: There are three primary ways to make calls within the platform. Regardless of the method, a dialog box will appear allowing you to select the phone number, manage call recording, and place the call.

items.title: Methods to Make Calls
items.text:
1. Contacts Page:

    • Navigate to the Contacts page.
    • Open the contact you wish to call.
    • Click on the call button associated with the contact.

  2. CRM Tickets:

    • Open the CRM Tickets page.
    • Locate the ticket associated with the contact you want to call.
    • Click on the call button within the ticket to initiate the call.

  3. Inbox:

    • Go to the Inbox page.
    • On the top right of each chat with a contact, there is a call button.
    • Click on this button to start a call with the contact.

items.title: Call Dialog Box
items.text:
When you click the call button using any of the above methods, a dialog box will appear as shown below:

  • Select Phone Number:
    • Choose the phone number you want to call from.
    • You can add a new number by clicking the "Add new number" button.
  • Call Recording:
    • Call recording is turned on by default.
    • You can turn off call recording for that particular call by toggling the ‚ÄúRecord Call‚Äù switch.
  • Place Call:
    • After selecting the phone number and setting your call recording preference, click on the "Place Call" button to initiate the call.
‚ùó Make sure to give Microphone Access to Messcat on your browser for Calls to work

items.title: Credit Pricing for calls
items.text:
• Per Minute Charging:
    • Credits are charged per minute for calls. If the call duration is less than a minute, a full minute‚Äôs worth of credits will be deducted.
  • Call Duration:
    • The call duration starts as soon as the call is made, not when it is picked up.
    • For example:
      • If the call duration is 1 minute and 23 seconds, credits will be deducted for 2 minutes.
      • If the call rings for 30 seconds but is not picked up, credits will be deducted for 1 minute.
üìå **Important Notes ‚Ä¢** Ensure you have the correct phone number selected before placing the call. **‚Ä¢** Call recording can be toggled according to your preference or requirements. **‚Ä¢** You can always add a new phone number directly from the call dialog box if needed. **‚Ä¢** Be mindful of the credit pricing to manage your credits efficiently.

items.title: How to use the Modify Contact node
items.text:
The "Modify Contact" node allows you to automate the process of updating contact information. This includes adding or removing tags, setting custom fields, and assigning chats to teammates or using round-robin assignment between multiple teammates.

  • Lead Qualification: Automatically add a "Qualified Lead" tag and set the custom field "Lead Score" to "High" when a contact meets certain criteria.
  • Customer Segmentation: Remove the "New Customer" tag and add the "Returning Customer" tag when a customer makes a repeat purchase.
  • Team Assignment: Assign chats from high-priority customers to senior support agents and distribute other chats evenly among the support team using round-robin.
‚ùó Modify Contact node can be used in after buttons, conditions or triggers
path: How to use the Modify Contact node

items.title: How to use the Modify Contact node
items.text:
• Name - This can be used to change the name of your contact. You can manually input a name or use a custom field
  • Add tag - Select the tag that you want to add from the dropdown
  • Remove tag - Select the tag that you want to remove from the dropdown
  • Set custom field - Set or update custom fields for the contact by clicking ‚ÄúAdd item‚Äù, selecting your custom field from the dropdown, and then setting its value
  • Remove custom field - Clear out the custom field for the contact by selecting it from the dropdown
  • Assignee - Select a specific teammate to assign the chats to. Select multiple teammates evenly distribute chats amongst them using round robin method
  • Remove Assignee - Enable this option to remove the assignee from the contact
path: How to use the Modify Contact node

items.title: How to use HTTP Request node
items.text:
Using this node, you can send HTTP(S) requests to external services or APIs. It allows you to connect Messcat with other systems and softwares

Ex: When a form is submitted in Messcat, you want to create a Google Calendar event
path: How to use HTTP Request node

items.title: How to use the HTTP request node
items.text:
There are two ways to send a HTTP request in Messcat:

üí° We suggest users to use the **HTTP Request Node** as it has lesser limitations compared to the **Action Node**
path: How to use HTTP Request node

items.title: Through the HTTP Request Node
items.text:
Step 1: Select ‚ÄúChoose next step‚Äù where you want use your HTTP request

Step 2: Select ‚ÄúHTTP Request‚Äù from the list

Step 3: Fill in the details of your HTTP Request
path: How to use HTTP Request node

items.title: Through the Action Node
items.text:
Step 1: Select ‚ÄúAdd Action‚Äù where you want use your HTTP request

Step 2: Within the Action Node, select the ‚ÄúHTTP Request‚Äù option

Step 3: Fill in the details of your HTTP Request, fire a test request, and click save after receiving a successful response

They both essentially perform the same tasks, but there are some slight differences as to how you can perform them:

HTTP Request Node Action Node Can be edited once created Cannot be edited once the test is successful and you leave the node (If you want to make changes later. you will have to delete this node and create a new one with the changes) Can only be used after Triggers, buttons, and lists Can be used after regular messages Can be saved without passing any tests HTTP Request can only be saved once you ‚ÄúFire test request‚Äù and there is a successful response
path: How to use HTTP Request node

items.title: How to fill the HTTP Request details?
items.text:
Step 1: Input the URL of the API endpoint you want to send your HTTP Request to. You can insert any variables related to the contact or custom field data by inputting a { (curly bracket) and selecting your property

Step 2: Select a method. Currently, we only support POST and GET methods

Step 3: Enter your headers (Name and Values). You can use any variables here as well

üí° We do not automatically add any headers such as ‚ÄúContent-Type‚Äù or ‚ÄúAccept‚Äù. If your API requires these, please add them manually in the headers section

Step 4: Fill in the body of your API request according to the third party‚Äôs documentation. You may use variables if you wish

Step 5(Only for Action Node): After setting up your HTTP Node, click ‚ÄúFire Test Request‚Äù. Only once you receive a successful response, you can save your message flow
path: How to use HTTP Request node

items.title: How to connect your Zapier to Messcat?
items.text: There are 3 ways to connect your Messcat account to Zapier:
path: How to connect Zapier to Messcat?

items.title: 1. Through Zapier‚Äôs website(Using Phone Number and Password)
items.text:
üí° Use this method if you have used a regular sign-up method with phone number and password(NOT google sign-up)

To connect your Messcat account to Zapier within a Zap using phone number and password, follow these steps:

  1. Head to Zapier and create a new Zap using the button on the top right

  2. Setup your Zap and select ‚ÄúMesscat‚Äù as the ‚ÄúApp‚Äù within the trigger or action based on your needs

  3. Select your trigger/action event from the available list

  4. In the ‚ÄúAccount‚Äù section, click on ‚ÄúConnect a new account‚Äù

  5. Within the popup, fill in the phone number and password you usually use to login to Messcat.

  6. If you are a part of multiple teams, fill the team ID field to ensure that you only use Zapier with your selected team. To find your team ID, go to Messcat, click on your profile icon on the top right, and click the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button next to your team name

  7. You can leave the Refresh Token empty, and click ‚ÄúYes, Continue to Messcat‚Äù

Your Messcat account is not connected to Zapier! You can continue building the rest of your ZAP according your requirements
path: How to connect Zapier to Messcat?

items.title: 2. Through Zapier‚Äôs website(Using Team ID and Refresh Token)
items.text:
üí° Use this method if you have opted for google sign-up(If you do not have a password)

If you do not login through the phone number and password combination, you can use Team ID and Refresh Token to connect your Messcat account to Zapier

  1. Follow steps 1 to 4 from the previous section
  2. Fill in the ‚ÄúTeam ID‚Äù and ‚ÄúRefresh Token‚Äù fields in the popup

  3. To find your team ID, go to Messcat, click on your profile icon on the top right, and click the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button next to your team name

  4. To get your refresh token, follow these steps:

    1. Head over to Messcat, hover over the ‚ÄúDeveloper‚Äù section in sidebar on the left-hand side, and click on ‚ÄúWebhook‚Äù

    2. Click the three dot menu in the top right corner and select ‚ÄúGenerate Refresh Token‚Äù

    3. In the popup, click on the ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù button

    4. Once your Refresh Token is generated, click the copy button and paste it in the ‚ÄúRefresh Token‚Äù section in Zapier

      ‚ÄºÔ∏è

      Make sure that you copy the token and save it securely, as you‚Äôll only be able to view it once

      ‚ÄºÔ∏è

      Refresh tokens expire after 14 days of no usage. If your token expires, please generate a new one and follow the same steps to connect your account again
path: How to connect Zapier to Messcat?

items.title: 2. Through Messcat‚Äôs website
items.text:
Within the Action Node of Messcat, you can easily create a new Zap. This integration allows you to leverage any of Zapier‚Äôs functions, enhancing your workflows by automating tasks directly through your message flows. The key requirement is that the Zap must be newly created within Messcat, ensuring a seamless and tailored automation experience right from the start.

‚ùó You can only connect one Zapier Account at a time and all team members can use that account. ‚ùó Only New Zaps can be created and no previously made Zaps can be used in message flows.
path: How to connect Zapier to Messcat?

items.title: How to import/export Message Flows
items.text:
Article Description: Learn how to import or export existing message flows them for backup or reuse

Message Flows allow you to automate conversations based on specific triggers and conditions. To streamline workflow management, you can import existing message flows or export them for backup or reuse.

items.title: Exporting a Message Flow
items.text:
Step 1: Hover over the navigation bar on the left side to find the ‚ÄúAutomation‚Äù section. Then, navigate to Message Flows

Step 2: Locate the message flow(s) you want to export and select them using the checkbox on the left side

Step 3: Click on the ‚ÄúExport‚Äù button below the search bar

Step 4: Select whether you want to include the values of the flow variables with your export or not. Find out more about flow variables here. Then, click ‚ÄúExport‚Äù

You will now have a ‚Äú.yaml‚Äù file downloaded. You can use this as a backup of your flows or to import them into a different team

items.title: Importing a Message Flow
items.text:
Step 1: Hover over the navigation bar on the left side to find the ‚ÄúAutomation‚Äù section. Then, navigate to Message Flows

Step 2: Click on the ‚ÄúImport‚Äù button on the top right

Step 3: Upload your ‚Äú.yaml‚Äù file of the flows you had previously exported.

Step 4: Select which flows you want to upload from the file and then click ‚ÄúImport‚Äù.

  • You can also preview the flows before uploading them
  • Select ‚ÄúInclude‚Äù to import all the selected flows
  • Select ‚ÄúExclude‚Äù to import all the flows other than the selected ones

items.title: How does Share Editing work?
items.text:
Share Editing is a powerful feature that allows you and your team to collaboratively edit automated message flows in almost real-time, similar to how Figma enables collaborative design work. With Share Editing, you can work together seamlessly, seeing each other's cursors and changes as they happen.

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1SwPJQuabXKzGUuU1-yYRTKijbkESAj0i/view?usp=drive_link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1SwPJQuabXKzGUuU1-yYRTKijbkESAj0i/view?usp=drive_link)

To start collaborating, simply enter the email or phone number connected to your teammate's Messcat account. Once added, you can send them the link created for them to join the editing session.

Share Editing also gives you control over who can view or edit the message flows. You can easily manage access and permissions, ensuring that only the right people have the right level of access.

Additionally, Share Editing offers a public view option, which allows you to see real-time changes made by others without the ability to edit. This can be useful for sharing progress with stakeholders or for training purposes.

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/12sJDRVG0tQ0lwuxAIcC1g4oFClAE0XGu/view?usp=drive_link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/12sJDRVG0tQ0lwuxAIcC1g4oFClAE0XGu/view?usp=drive_link)
path: How to edit message flows with your team?

items.title: How to create a calendar booking system using Google Calendar
items.text:
Use ‚ÄúGenerate Calendar slots‚Äù and ‚ÄúCalendar‚Äù to create your own booking system

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/16yTYklpwQIyl8babAw_nGTNr7EyTEBAQ/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/16yTYklpwQIyl8babAw_nGTNr7EyTEBAQ/view?usp=sharing)

The Calendar apps allow you to integrate a Google Calendar booking system for your business through message flows. There are 2 nodes available to help you achieve this:

  1. Generate Calendar Slots - The Generate Calendar Slots app will return a list of available time slots on the date your client wants to book an appointment
  2. Calendar - The Calendar app will create the booking and send you and your client a google invite based on the date and time they select for the booking

These apps allows you to:

  • Integrate your google account with Messcat to
  • Set the days when you want to accept bookings. Ex: Monday to Friday
  • Set what time you want to start and end your bookings. Ex: 9:00 to 18:00
  • Set the duration of your bookings. Ex: 1 hour
  • Add a location of your meeting(if any). If no location is added it will automatically create and schedule a google meet
path: How to create a calendar booking system using Google Calendar

items.title: Steps to create the booking system:
items.text:
Step 1: Go to Automations > Message Flows > Create new flow

Step 2: Create a starting message requesting your client to specify the date when they want to setup an appointment. Ex: ‚ÄúPlease enter the date in DD MM format. For example, 2 September.‚Äù

The date The date MUST be in DD MM format. The flow will not work otherwise

Step 3: Add a ‚ÄúUser Input‚Äù and save the response to a ‚ÄúDate‚Äù type custom field

Step 4 (Optional): Ask your user to input their email ID if you want to send them an invite to the appointment

Step 5 (Optional): Add a ‚ÄúUser Input‚Äù and save the response to a ‚ÄúText‚Äù type custom field

Step 6: Add and setup your ‚ÄúGeneral Calendar Slots‚Äù app

  1. Click on ‚ÄúAdd Integration‚Äù(if you don‚Äôt already have one) or select the calendar account you want to use

  2. In the ‚ÄúDate‚Äù input, add the custom field where you saved your Date in Step 3 by typing {{field_name}}

    Replace field_name with the name of your custom field

    1. Input the start and end timings of your booking system, along with the duration of each appointment
    2. Select the the days when you want to take in bookings

Step 7: Click on ‚ÄúChoose next step‚Äù and select message. You can use the output of the General Calendar Slots app by using this variable: {{Formatted Slots}}

Ex:

Select your appointment timings from these slots: {{Formatted Slots}}

Step 8: Add a ‚ÄúUser Input‚Äù and save the response to a ‚ÄúText‚Äù type custom field

Step 9: Add and setup your ‚ÄúCalendar‚Äù app

  1. Click on ‚ÄúAdd Integration‚Äù(if you don‚Äôt already have one) or select the calendar account you want to use

  2. Setup the Date, Bookings Start, Bookings End, and Booking Duration with the same details as you did in Step 6

    Make sure the details match in both the calendar nodes

    1. In the ‚ÄúContact Name‚Äù, add the name of your client by typing {name}
    2. In the ‚ÄúContact Email‚Äù, add the custom field where you saved your Email in Step 5 by typing {{field_name}}
    3. (Optional) Add a location for your meeting if it is a physical appointment

Step 10: Send a confirmation message with the Google Calendar link using the variable {{Message}}
path: How to create a calendar booking system using Google Calendar

items.title: How to fix ‚ÄúA template is required to start a new conversation‚Äù Issue
path: How to fix ‚ÄúA template is required to start a new conversation‚Äù Issue

items.title: What does this issue mean?
items.text:
If you are using a WABA or WhatsApp Business account, there are some limitations that WhatsApp enforces when you are messaging a new contact:

  1. If you are messaging a new contact who you have never contacted before, you must use a ‚ÄúTemplate‚Äù that is approved by WhatsApp
  2. Once you start messaging a contact, that particular conversation lasts 24 hours. After this time period, you can only start another conversation using a ‚ÄúTemplate‚Äù that is approved by WhatsApp
path: How to fix ‚ÄúA template is required to start a new conversation‚Äù Issue

items.title: What is a "Template"?
items.text: Template messages are pre-approved messages used for marketing, utility, and authentication communications with customers. They are required when starting conversations with customers who haven't contacted the business before or haven't communicated in the past 24 hours. These templates require approval and are subject to deactivation if customers report them negatively. If templates are disabled due to low quality ratings or policy violations, they remain unusable until the issues are fixed.
path: How to fix ‚ÄúA template is required to start a new conversation‚Äù Issue

items.title: How to submit a template for approval to WhatsApp

  1. Access 'Automation' in Messcat and select 'Messages Flow'.
  2. Click '+Create New Flow', then choose your desired template or select 'Start from Scratch'.
  3. Edit/create your flow as required

  4. Click on the 3 dot menu on the top right and then select

  5. Choose your Channel, Category, and Language, and click 'Submit'.

  6. You can check the submission status of the template in the template editor; Once a template is submitted, the approval process may take up to 24 hours.

items.title: Limitations
items.text:
While creating a message template to submit for review for WABA account, please refer below for the message template‚Äôs setting limitations.

| Button | Either [URL button] or [phone number button] The combination will be either one of the below: 1. new message + URL button 2. new message + phone number button 3. new message + new message

  • Maximum of 25 characters in Button name. | | --- | --- | | Delay | [Delay] action cannot apply to the ‚ÄúStarting Step‚Äù message. | | List | [List] action cannot apply to the ‚ÄúStarting Step‚Äù message. | | User Input | [User input] feature is not allowed. | | Voice Message | [Voice Message] cannot be inserted. | | Image | media files format: image/jpeg, image/png maximum size: 5MB

items.title: Why was my template rejected?
items.text:
Submissions are commonly rejected for the following reasons, so make sure you avoid these mistakes.

  • Variable parameters are missing or have mismatched curly braces. The correct format is {{1}}.
  • Variable parameters contain special characters such as a #, $, or %.
  • The message template contains content that violates WhatsApp‚Äôs Commerce Policy: When you offer goods or services for sale, we consider all messages and media related to your goods or services, including any descriptions, prices, fees, taxes and/or any required legal disclosures, to constitute transactions. Transactions must comply with the WhatsApp Commerce Policy.
  • The message template contains content that violates the WhatsApps Business Policy: Do not request sensitive identifiers from users. For example, do not ask people to share full length individual payment card numbers, financial account numbers, National Identification numbers, or other sensitive identifiers. This also includes not requesting documents from users that might contain sensitive identifiers. Requesting partial identifiers (ex: last 4 digits of their Social Security number) is OK.
  • The content contains potentially abusive or threatening content, such as threatening a customer with legal action or threatening to publicly shame them.
  • The message template is a duplicate of an existing template. If a template is submitted with the same wording in the body and footer of an existing template, the duplicate template will be rejected.

A rejection notification that includes the rejection reason will appear in Business Support Home. You can view rejections in the Business Support Home by navigating to Account Overview > View my accounts (button) > (your Meta Business Account) > (your WABA) > Rejected message templates. Rejection info will also be sent via email.

You can refer to the Business Support Home notification to see the name and language of the existing template with the same content as the rejected duplicate template. You may also choose to edit the template and resubmit.This check does not apply to templates categorised as AUTHENTICATION.
path: How to fix ‚ÄúA template is required to start a new conversation‚Äù Issue

items.title: Messages Template Status (WABA)
items.text:
Templates can have the following statuses.

  • In-Review: Indicates that the template is still under review. Review can take up to 24 hours.
  • Rejected: The template has been rejected during our review process or violates one or more of our policies.
  • Active - Quality pending: The message template has yet to receive quality feedback from customers. Message templates with this status can be sent to customers.
  • Active - High Quality: The template has received little to no negative customer feedback. Message templates with this status can be sent to customers.
  • Active - Medium Quality: The template has received negative feedback from multiple customers but may soon become paused or disabled. Message templates with this status can be sent to customers.
  • Active - Low Quality: The template has received negative feedback from multiple customers. Message templates with this status can be sent to customers but are in danger of being paused or disabled soon, so we recommend that you address the issues that customers are reporting.
  • Paused: The template has been paused due to recurring negative feedback from customers. Message templates with this status cannot be sent to customers.
  • Disabled: The template has been disabled due to recurring negative feedback from customers. Message templates with this status cannot be sent to customers.
  • Appeal Requested: Indicates that an appeal has been requested. See Appeals. The appeal will be reviewed and a decision made within 24 hours.

You can view a template's status by going to WhatsApp Manager > Overview, mousing over the suitcase icon (Account tools) and clicking Message templates. If you have multiple WhatsApp Business Accounts, select the account whose template statuses you want to view from the list of accounts in the dropdown menu in the top-right corner.

items.title: What are delay nodes
items.text:
Delay nodes are essential tools in creating effective and engaging automated message flows. They allow you to follow up with your customers after a certain period of time in case they don‚Äôt reply, which can be especially useful for WABA users who have a conversation window of 24 hours. You can also use it to set automatic follow ups after a product sale to gather customer reviews or sell other related products after some time (like insurance renewals)

‚ùó It is compulsory to have a delay node between 2 message nodes. You cannot have 2 message nodes following each other. ‚ùó A delay node must have a valid message node before and after it. These messages cannot be empty.

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/13GtQPfZHQXVmI7hcUGoA4vfwg2lk6Tqe/view?usp=drive_link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/13GtQPfZHQXVmI7hcUGoA4vfwg2lk6Tqe/view?usp=drive_link)

items.title: Types of delay nodes
items.text:
There are 3 types of delay nodes:

  1. Duration - Add a delay of the exact duration you want to send your next message after

    Ex: You want to follow up with a customer who has not responded in 1 hour

  2. Date - Send your next message on a specific date at a specific time

    Ex: You‚Äôre hosting a webinar on 25/06/2024 at 10:00 AM and you want to send a reminder 1 day before

  3. Weekday with time - **Select when to send your next message based on the day of the week

    Ex: You want to promote your YouTube video which comes out Next Tuesday at 9:00 AM

items.title: Show ‚Äútyping...‚Äù during display
items.text: Select this checkbox if you want to make the interaction feel more human and engaging by showing ‚Äútyping‚Äù on WhatsApp before the message is sent out.

items.title: Cancel message if reply received
items.text: This option ensures that any scheduled follow up messages are automatically canceled if a reply is received from the recipient before the message is sent. So you can send an automated follow up message using delays and if the customer replies before the set time, the message will be canceled.

items.title: How to use conditions
items.text: The conditions block allows you to change your customer interactions based on where they live, a particular tag, their assignee, and much more.

items.title: Step-by-Step Guide
items.text:
1. Navigate to the message flow where you want to add conditions
  2. Click on the "Condition" block and then on ‚ÄúCheck Condition‚Äù to open the condition settings
  3. You will see an option to specify if "All" or "Any" of the conditions should match. This allows you to determine whether all specified conditions must be met (AND logic) or if any one of them can trigger the action (OR logic).
  4. In the dropdown, you will see various properties such as Unique ID, Channel, Name, Phone Number, Tag, Country, Assignee, and more. Select the property that you want to use as a condition.
  5. Once you select a property, specify whether the condition "is" or "is not" met. In some cases such as Name, Phone number etc, you will also see options like ‚Äúcontains‚Äù, ‚Äústarts with‚Äù, ‚Äúends with‚Äù, etc.
  6. Next, you will see a list of possible values. For the Channel property, this includes various phone numbers. For properties like Name, you can input custom values. Check the appropriate boxes to select the specific channels you want to include or exclude.
  7. If you want to add more conditions, go to the ‚ÄúIf not‚Äù section and click on ‚ÄúCheck Another Condition‚Äù
  8. Continue building your message flow by choosing the next step or adding further conditions

Here are the available condition options and how you can use them:

Contact/ Contact Updated/ New Contact Properties

  • Unique ID

  • Channel

    Specify the channel name to condition. The following message will only be sent if the contact does or does not belong to that channel.

    Example: If a contact belongs to the "Malaysia" channel, send them a special discount code for the Deepawali holiday.

  • Name

  • Phone number
  • Tag
  • Country
  • Assignee
  • Messages received
  • Messages sent
  • Type (Individual/Group)
  • Ticket stage
  • Ticket ID

items.title: Difference Between Contact Properties and Contact Updated Properties
items.text:
• Contact Properties

    Use this when you want to check a contact‚Äôs property, regardless of whether it was just updated.

    Example: To check if "John" is the assignee, and you don‚Äôt care when the assignment was made, use "Contact Properties."

  • Contact Updated Properties

    Use this to check if a specific property of the contact has just been updated, causing the trigger.

    Example: If the assignee was just updated to "John" and you want to verify that change specifically, use "Contact Updated Properties."

Key Use Case:

"Contact Updated Properties" is especially useful when multiple conditions, like adding a "Responded" tag and assigning "John" as the assignee, are applied simultaneously in one node (e.g., a Modify Contact node).

Incoming/Outgoing Message Properties

  • Text
  • Time
  • Channel
  • Chat ID
  • Is Button Click
  • Sender(Outgoing messages only)

AI Chatbot Response

  • Successful Response
  • Reply

Context

  • Time of event

Miscellaneous

  • Custom

items.title: How to add buttons and lists in message flows
items.text:
Learn the difference between buttons and lists, and how to use them in Messcat!

Interactive messages provide users with a simpler, more efficient way to interact with your business on WhatsApp. They achieve significantly higher response rates and conversions compared to traditional text-based messages.

Messcat supports two types of interactive messages:

  1. Buttons: Quick-select options with up to 3 buttons.
  2. Lists: A menu-style format with up to 10 options.
‚ùó **Important** - You can only use **EITHER buttons or lists** in a single message. - These features are available **only** for WhatsApp Business or WABA accounts. - Without these accounts, messages will be sent as poll buttons.

items.title: What are Triggers?
items.text:
Triggers are a powerful functionality within message flows that enable automated responses and workflows, streamlining communication and operational processes. By setting specific conditions or events as triggers, you can automatically send messages or initiate complex workflows without manual intervention.

Triggers have the power to replace all automation modules (broadcasts, keyword replies, offline bot, shop notifications) and much more

items.title: Types of triggers
items.text:
• Incoming Message: Activated whenever a new message is received.
  • Outgoing Message: Activated whenever there is a new message sent.
  • New Chat: Activated whenever the first message is sent or received in a new chat.
  • Contact Updated: Triggered when contact information is modified.
  • Contact Added: Initiated upon the addition of a new contact.
  • Ticket Updated: Activated whenever there is a change in a ticket.
  • Ticket Created: Activated whenever there is a new ticket created.
  • Broadcast: Facilitates sending broadcast messages to multiple contacts simultaneously.

items.title: What is Trigger Frequency?
items.text:
Trigger Frequency lets you control how often an automation (like an Incoming Message flow) can be triggered per contact within a set time window.

This helps prevent spammy behavior or repeated automation responses when a contact sends multiple messages in a short period.

For example:

If you set it to ‚ÄúOnce per 30 seconds‚Äù, each contact can only trigger this automation once every 30 seconds‚Äîno matter how many messages they send during that time.

items.title: New Note Trigger
items.text:
Article Description: Learn how to use the ‚ÄúNew Note‚Äù Trigger!

üí° The New Note trigger is activated every time any chat has a new note added to it

items.title: Overview
items.text:
The New Note trigger allows you to automate workflows whenever a new note is added to a conversation. This trigger is useful for tracking important updates, notifying team members, or integrating notes with external systems.

To learn more about how to add and use notes, click on this link

items.title: Use Cases
items.text:
• Internal Notifications: Alert team members when a new note is added to a high-priority conversation.
  • CRM Updates: Automatically update CRM records when a new note is logged with certain keywords.
  • Ticket Escalation: Trigger an escalation workflow if a note contains specific keywords.
  • External Syncing: Sync notes with third-party tools like Google Sheets, Slack, or a project management app.

items.title: Trigger Conditions
items.text:
You can customize the trigger with the following conditions:

  • Note Content: Contains specific words or phrases.
  • Author: Notes added by specific users or roles.
  • Conversation/Ticket Status: Trigger only if the associated item is open, pending, or closed.
  • Tagged Notes: Only activate for notes with a specific tag.

items.title: Scenario: Notify a Manager When a Critical Note is Added
items.text:
1. Trigger: New Note is added.
  2. Condition: If the note contains "urgent" or "escalate".
  3. Action: Send a Slack notification to the manager.
  4. Action: Send an in-notification to teammate on Messcat

items.title: Note Resolved Trigger
items.text:
Article Description: Learn how to use the ‚ÄúNote Resolved‚Äù Trigger!

üí° The Note Resolved trigger is activated every time any note has been resolved

items.title: Overview
items.text: The Note Resolved trigger activates when a previously added note is marked as resolved. This is useful for tracking completed tasks, notifying team members, and updating external systems based on note resolutions.

items.title: Use Cases
items.text:
• Internal Alerts: Notify relevant team members when a note is resolved.
  • Task Management: Mark tasks as complete in external project management tools.
  • CRM Updates: Change the status of CRM entries based on note resolution.
  • Automated Follow-Ups: Trigger a follow-up message or email when a note is resolved.

items.title: Trigger Conditions
items.text:
Customize the trigger using the following conditions:

  • Resolved by: Activate when a specific user or role resolves the note.
  • Related Item Status: Trigger only if the associated conversation, ticket, or CRM entry is in a certain state (e.g., open, pending, closed).
  • Resolution Tags: Only trigger for notes marked with a particular tag upon resolution.
  • Resolved At: Trigger based on the timestamp of when the note was resolved.

items.title: Scenario: Notify a Supervisor When a Critical Note Is Resolved
items.text:
1. Trigger: A note is marked as resolved.
  2. Condition: If the note contains ‚Äúurgent‚Äù or ‚Äúhigh priority.‚Äù
  3. Action: Send an email notification to the supervisor.

items.title: Automating Comments with Triggers (Instagram & Messenger)
items.text: Last Updated: March 27, 2025

items.title: Intro
items.text:
![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image.png)

Want to automatically reply to comments based on specific words or posts? Messcat's Triggers make it possible!

This guide shows you how to use Triggers to create advanced automations for responding to comments on your Instagram and Messenger posts.

items.title: You can start with the template below
items.text: ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%201.png)

items.title: Or follow these steps to create one from scratch
items.text:
Step 1: Create a New Trigger

  • Go to your Messcat automation > Message Flow.

  • Click "Trigger" > Create a new Facebook/Instagram Comment trigger.

    ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%202.png)

Step 2: Add Conditions

  • Add a "Condition" node to your trigger.

    ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%203.png)

  • Click "Add Condition" to see all available options. You can set conditions based on:

    ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%204.png)

    • Text: The comment's content

    • Post: A specific post you select

      ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%205.png)

    • Post's caption

    • And more!
üí° **Example: Responding to "Nice" Comments on #engagement Posts** - You want to automatically reply to anyone who comments "Nice" on posts with the hashtag #engagement. - Set a condition for "Text" contain "Nice". - Set a condition for "Post Caption" to contain "#engagement". - You can also add an action to automatically add a tag (like "Comment") to these users.

Step 3: Choose Next Step and Send a Message to the Customer

  • After setting your conditions, decide what message to send.
  • Add a "Send Message" action.
  • Write the message you want to send as a private reply (DM) to the user.

  • You can customize the message based on the condition that triggered the automation.

    ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%206.png)

Optional Step 4: Adding Automation (Examples: Adding a Tag)

  • Beyond simply sending a message, you can automate other actions.
  • For example, you can add a tag to users who trigger the automation.
    • Add an "Add Tag" action.
    • Choose or create a tag (e.g., "Comment").

    • This helps you track who commented on your posts and segment your audience.

      ![image.png](Automating%20Comments%20with%20Triggers%20(Instagram%20&%20Mes/image%207.png)

items.title: What Happens Next?
items.text: When someone comments and meets your trigger conditions, Messcat will automatically send your reply as a private message (DM).

items.title: Incoming message trigger
items.text: üí°  The incoming message trigger is activated whenever there is a new message received.

items.title: Using incoming message trigger to send automated replies
items.text:

For ex: When customer sends a message which contains the word ‚Äúhelp‚Äù in it, you can trigger a specific response

Step 2: Add a condition for text, and input the keyword you want to reply to

items.text:

items.title: Outgoing message trigger
items.text: üí° The outgoing message trigger is activated whenever there is a new message sent.

items.title: Using outgoing message trigger to modify contact and update ticket.
items.text:
Using the "Outgoing Message" trigger and conditions, you can modify contact properties and also update CRM tickets.

For ex: When you send a message which contains the word ‚Äúresolve‚Äù in it, you can modify contacts info and update their ticket.

Step 2: Add a condition for a specific channel, a condition for text, and input the keyword you want it to check, and a condition for a specific tag

Step 4: Add a Update Ticket App Node, which can change the status of a particular ticket of that contact

üí° You can use conditions to filter out the contacts based on tags, what type of messages you want to respond to, which channel you want to enable the trigger for, time of the message, and much more

items.title: New Chat Trigger
items.text: üí° The New Chat trigger is activated whenever the first message is sent or received in a new chat.

items.title: Using the New Chat trigger to sent automated greetings message
items.text:
Using the ‚ÄúNew Chat‚Äù trigger, you can send your customers automated greeting or welcome messages to your new or potential clients

For ex: When someone sends a message for the first time to your number, you want to greet them and give them some starting options

Step 1: Go to message flows and add a ‚ÄúNew Chat‚Äù trigger

Step 2: Click on ‚ÄúChoose Next Step‚Äù and select condition. You can add conditions for channels and whether the first message is incoming or outgoing

Step 3: Click on ‚ÄúChoose Next Step‚Äù, select Message, and draft the message you want to sent to your customer.

Step 4(Optional): Build a more complex flow by adding more conditions, follow up messages, adding tags to your contacts, and assigning them to your team members

items.title: Difference Between Contact Properties and Contact Updated Properties when using condition with Contact Updated Trigger
items.text:
Contact Properties

  • Use this when you want to check a contact‚Äôs property, regardless of whether it was just updated.
  • Example: To check if "John" is the assignee and you don‚Äôt care when the assignment was made, use "Contact Properties."

Contact Updated Properties

  • Use this to check if a specific property of the contact has just been updated, causing the trigger.
  • Example: If the assignee was just updated to "John" and you want to verify that change specifically, use "Contact Updated Properties."
  • Key Use Case for Contact Updated Properties
    • "Contact Updated Properties" is particularly useful when multiple conditions need to be met in the same instance.
    • Example: If a "Responded" tag is added and "John" is assigned as the assignee simultaneously (e.g., in a Modify Contact node), you can use Contact Updated Properties to ensure the trigger is based on these updates.

items.text: üí° The New Contact trigger Initiated upon the addition of a new contact to Messcat

items.title: Using the New Contact Trigger
items.text: You can use this trigger to send a message flow when a new contact has been added. This allows you to automatically start workflows or send welcome messages to new contacts as soon as they are added to your system, ensuring timely and efficient engagement with new customers.
